references: Furthermore, many of these algorithms, including FedAvg, STEM, FedProx, MIME, and CE-SGD, still rely on the assumption of bounded data heterogeneity. When this assumption is violated, the theoretical analyses of these algorithms become invalid. While some algorithms, such as LED (Alghunaim, 2023) and VRL-SGD (Liang etÂ al., 2019), can handle unbounded data heterogeneity, their convergence rates are not state-of-the-art, as demonstrated in Table 1. These limitations motivate us to develop novel strategies that are easy to implement, robust to data heterogeneity, and exhibit superior theoretical convergence rates.

Table 1 compares FedAvg-M with existing algorithms when all clients participate in the training process. The results demonstrate that FedAvg-M attains the most favorable convergence rate without relying on any assumption of data heterogeneity. Moreover, this rate matches the lower bound provided by (Arjevani etÂ al., 2019).

FedAvg-M-VR surpasses all existing variance-reduced federated learning methods in terms of convergence rate, as demonstrated by the results presented in Table 1. Additionally, when compared to BVR-L-SGD (Murata & Suzuki, 2021) and CE-LSGD (Patel etÂ al., 2022), FedAvg-M-VR computes each local stochastic gradient using a batchsize of ğ’ªâ€‹(1)ğ’ª1\displaystyle\mathcal{O}(1), contrasting with the Oâ€‹(K)ğ‘‚ğ¾\displaystyle O(K) batchsize employed by BVR-L-SGD and CE-LSGD. Furthermore, in comparison to STEM (Khanduri etÂ al., 2021), FedAvg-M-VR does not rely on the assumption of bounded data heterogeneity.

SCAFFOLD-M-VR outperforms all existing variance-reduced federated learning methods under partial participation in terms of convergence rate when data heterogeneity is severe (i.e., Î¶2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\zeta^{2} is large), see results listed in Table 2. Moreover, SCAFFOLD-M-VR has the following additional advantages. Compared to MimeLiteMVR (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020a), SCAFFOLD-M-VR does not need access to noiseless (full-batch) local gradients per iteration.
Compared to MB-STORM (Patel etÂ al., 2022) and CE-LSGD (Patel etÂ al., 2022), SCAFFOLD-M-VR does not require bounded data heterogeneity and computes each gradient efficiently with batchsize 11\displaystyle 1, as opposed to batchsize ğ’ªâ€‹(K)ğ’ªğ¾\displaystyle\mathcal{O}(K).
